title: Obtain and Prepare Water in Arctic Conditions
brief: Safely melt ice and snow for drinking water while conserving body heat and fuel.
steps: Step 1: Use old sea ice (rounded corners, bluish color) as it has lost salinity over time.
Step 2: Melt ice rather than snow when possible - one cup ice yields more water than one cup snow.
Step 3: Completely melt ice or snow before putting in mouth - prevents internal cold injury.
Step 4: Start with small amount in container near fire, add more as it melts.
Step 5: Use body heat method: place snow in water bag between clothing layers for slow melting on the move.
Step 6: Keep melted water next to body to prevent refreezing.
Step 7: Don't fill canteen completely - allow sloshing to prevent freezing.
warnings: Never try to melt ice or snow in your mouth - removes body heat and causes internal cold injuries.
Don't waste fuel melting ice/snow when other drinkable water sources available.
Avoid drinking lots of liquid before bed - reduces sleep and increases cold exposure.
